Poulton Portrait of Lajos Kossuth 1860s.jpg|thumb|upright|Lajos Kossuth, Regent-President during the Hungarian Revolution of 1848 File:Austria-Hungary map.svg|thumb|upright|The Lands of the Crown of Saint Stephen consisted of the territories of the Kingdom of Hungary (16) and the Kingdom of Croatia-Slavonia (17). Between 1703 and 1711, there was a large-scale war of independence led by Francis II Rákóczi, who after the dethronement of the Habsburgs in 1707 at the Diet of Ónod, took power provisionally as the ruling prince for the wartime period, but refused the Hungarian crown and the title "king". The uprisings lasted for years. The Hungarian Kuruc army, although taking over most of the country, lost the main battle at Trencsén (1708). Three years later, because of the growing desertion, defeatism, and low morale, the Kuruc forces finally surrendered.    During the Napoleonic Wars and afterward, the Hungarian Diet had not convened for decades.   In the 1820s, the emperor was forced to convene the Diet, which marked the beginning of a Reform Period (1825–1848,
